Literally, what I mean is you got one foot in the old code, you got your other foot in the new code. When youâ€™re doing a refactoring, you always want to have this moment when you have both codes in place and working so that before you turn off the old code, the new code is working. If you step forward too far, if you remove the old code and then you have nothing that works and then you write the new code and you make it work. I call that ripping your bridges, that you have that moment in time when no code works and solves the thing. I would agree with you that if you want to plunge ahead and then go back and squash commits so that the PR is still green, Iâ€™m totally down with that. Iâ€™m totally fine with that. SARON:Â  I like that name. DEREK:Â  Yes, itâ€™s a good name. SARON:Â  Now that youâ€™ve explained anyway, it makes a lot of sense. DAVID:Â  If you draw on a whiteboard over time, you have two rows. You just draw a bar graph of â€˜hereâ€™s the old code and itâ€™s working right up until we remove itâ€™. Then you take the new code in green and you draw a bar graph off of â€˜hereâ€™s when we got it working and here it is working on into the futureâ€™. Itâ€™s very obvious when you look at that graph that if those bars overlap, then at some point, you have both codes working.
